title: Patient with CKD
summary: 58-year-old with A1c 8.6%, eGFR 42 mL/min/1.73 m², obesity, and history of nocturnal hypoglycemia on prior secretagogue.
teachingPoint: Prioritize agents with demonstrated cardiorenal benefit and avoid hypoglycemia-prone regimens. SGLT2 inhibitors are recommended for individuals with CKD regardless of A1C (Diabetes Canada 2024; CCS 2022).

title: Patient with ASCVD
summary: 64-year-old with prior MI, A1c 8.1%, BMI 36. Motivated for weight loss and stroke prevention.
teachingPoint: Use GLP-1 RA or SGLT2i for cardiorenal risk reduction. GLP-1 RAs have strong evidence for MACE and nonfatal stroke reduction; preferred when weight loss is a priority (Diabetes Canada 2024; CCS 2022).

title: Patient with Heart Failure
summary: 62-year-old with HFrEF (LVEF 35%), A1c 7.8%, eGFR 58. On guideline-directed HF therapy; need to add glucose-lowering with cardiorenal benefit.
teachingPoint: SGLT2 inhibitors are recommended for adults with HF (LVEF ≤40% or >40%) to reduce hospitalization for HF and, in HFrEF, mortality and kidney outcomes. Initiation is independent of A1C (CCS 2022; Diabetes Canada 2024).

title: Cost-Sensitive, New Diagnosis
summary: 47-year-old, A1c 8.4%, no ASCVD/CKD/HF, limited drug coverage. Tolerates metformin.
teachingPoint: Metformin remains first-line when tolerated and affordable. Sulfonylureas are the least expensive alternative where financial barriers exist; consider hypoglycemia and weight when choosing (Diabetes Canada 2024).

title: Patient with GI Intolerance to Metformin
summary: 55-year-old, A1c 8.2%, eGFR 78, ASCVD. Cannot tolerate metformin due to persistent GI symptoms despite slow titration.
teachingPoint: In ASCVD with need for weight loss, prefer SGLT2i when GLP-1 RA is limited by GI intolerance. SGLT2i offer cardiorenal benefit without GI burden (Diabetes Canada 2024; CCS 2022).
